- Barcelona is the capital and largest city of Catalonia, located in the Spanish Levant on the Mediterranean coast.
- Geographical coordinates: 41°16' - 41°30' N, 1°54' - 2°18' E.
- Area: 102.16 km².
- Bordered by the sea, Collserola mountain range, and deltas of the Besós and Llobregat rivers.
- Highest point: Tibidabo summit (516.2 m).
- Coast has several undulations due to former torrents and a general slope from sea to Collserola mountain range.
- Crossed by faults, mainly with a northeast-southwest orientation.
- Terrain formed by slate, granitic formations, clays, and limestones.
- Mediterranean climate with mild winters and low rainfall (600 mm/year).
- Vegetation: pines, evergreen oaks, heather, laurestine, arbutus, and climbing plants.
- Formerly agricultural, now mostly built-up area.
- Second most populous city in Spain (1,604,555 inhabitants in 2015) and eleventh most populous in the EU.
- Divided into 10 districts and 73 neighborhoods.

Ciutat Vella district:
- Corresponds to the old core of the city, including Roman and medieval periods, and the Barceloneta neighborhood.
- Received immigration from other parts of Spain during the 19th and 20th centuries, and from other countries in the 21st century.
- Oldest and lowest socioeconomic level population in the city.
- Gentrification process beginning in parallel to urban development plans.

- Barcelona is divided into 10 districts and 73 neighborhoods.

Ciutat Vella:
- Oldest part of the city, derived from Roman and medieval periods.
- 4.49 km², 100 685 inhabitants.
- Received immigration from the rest of Spain during the 19th and 20th centuries, and from other countries in the 21st century.
- Oldest and lowest socioeconomic level population in the city.
- Gentrification process in progress.
- Numerous monuments and architectural works of interest.
- Houses important institutions such as City Hall or the Generalitat de Catalunya.

Eixample:
- Arose from the expansion of the old city after the demolition of the walls.
- 7.46 km², 263,565 inhabitants.
- Densely populated district.
- Originally a residential area for wealthy families.
- Social level corresponds mainly to the middle class.
- Important focus of tourist attraction due to modernist architectural works.

Sants-Montjuïc:
- Includes the old town of Sants and Montjuïc mountain.
- 21.35 km², 180,824 inhabitants.
- Largest district of the city.
- Low population density.
- High percentage of green area due to Montjuïc mountain.
- High percentage of foreign population.

Les Corts:
- Comes from the old town of Les Corts de Sarrià, added to the city in 1897.
- 6.08 km², 81,200 inhabitants.
- Predominance of single-family houses.
- High rate of young people.
- Economy dominated by tertiary sector.

Sarrià-Sant Gervasi:
- Comes from the union of two former municipalities, Sarrià and Sant Gervasi de Cassoles.
- 20.09 km², 145,761 inhabitants.
- Largest district, includes a large part of the Collserola mountain range.
- Lowest population density.
- Economy dominated by quality facilities, private schools

- 73 neighborhoods established in Barcelona, with some controversy due to fragmentation of historical neighborhoods and unmet aspirations of some neighborhood units.
- Barcelona founded by Roman colonizers in the first century BC as Barcino, originally a small walled city on Mons Taber hill near the coast with a natural harbor.
- During the second century, Barcino reached its maximum splendor with a population of 3500-5000 inhabitants.
- The Roman city had an orthogonal layout with square or rectangular blocks based on two main axes, collected by Ildefonso Cerdá in his Plan de Eixample of 1859.
- Romans provided the territory with roads, bridges, aqueducts, and urban design with basic services like sewerage.
- The city was walled with a perimeter of 1.5 km, initially with a simple wall and later reinforced with a double wall of 2 meters in the 4th century with 74 towers.
- Remains from the Roman period include a necropolis with over 70 tombs in Plaça de la Vila de Madrid and remnants of two aqueducts.
- After the fall of the Roman Empire and until the formation of the Catalan counties, the city was used as a military stronghold and experienced suburbanization with the appearance of the first suburbs.
- Barcelona became a county, then part of the Crown of Aragon, and the political and economic center of the Principality of Catalonia during the Middle Ages.
- Barcelona became an important maritime and commercial axis of the Mediterranean Sea.

- Reuse of Roman city structure in medieval period
- Barcelona became a military stronghold, gaining hegemony over surrounding cities and becoming capital of its territory
- Colonization of countryside began with feudal system and suburbanization started
- Barcelona was constituted as a county and later part of the Crown of Aragon, becoming the political and economic center of the Principality of Catalonia
- City grew from the Gothic Quarter and had about 25,000 inhabitants in the 14th century
- City acquired autonomy and became center of a hinterland
- Council of One Hundred established in 1265 to govern the city
- Jewish quarter, the Call, existed from 692 to 1391, with two synagogues, baths, schools, and hospitals
- Plain of Barcelona was used for agriculture, especially to supply the city
- Canals built in the 10th century to direct waters of Llobregat and Besòs rivers to vicinity of city
- First settlements outside city walls established around churches and monasteries in the 13th century
- New neighborhoods formed, including Raval, leading to the construction of a new wall in 1260.

- Raval neighborhood was initially a suburb with orchards and religious buildings such as Sant Pau del Camp (914), Sant Antoni Abat (1157), Carmelites Calçats (1292), Nazareth (1342), Montalegre (1362), and Montcada (1390).
- A new wall was built in 1260 from Sant Pere de les Puelles to the Drassanes, facing the sea, which was 5100 m long and covered an area of 1.5 km². It had eighty towers and eight new gates, including the Portal de l'Àngel, Portaferrissa, and La Boqueria.
- Fortifications were built in the urban periphery for the defense of the city, such as the castle of the Port, Martorell, Castellví de Rosanes, Eramprunyà, Castelldefels, and Montcada.
- The medieval urban fabric was marked by different areas of influence, including aristocracy, institutional power, bishopric, religious orders, guilds, and trade associations.
- Houses were usually of the "artisan type," with a first floor for the workshop and one or two floors for living, measuring 4 m wide and 10-12 m deep. Larger buildings were churches, palaces, institutional buildings, hospitals, and buildings such as the Llotja or the Drassanes.
- In 1209, the opening of Montcada street took place, a wide, straight street running from the Bòria to the sea, occupied by large stately residences.
- The Plaça Nova was opened in 1355, next to the Episcopal Palace and near the cathedral of Barcelona.
- Between the 14th and 15th centuries, the continuous urban growth led to a new extension of the walled enclosure, the Raval wall, which covered an area of 218 ha, with a perimeter of 6 km.
- In 1444, La Rambla was urbanized, which was then the widest space in the city, dedicated to strolling, leisure, or the installation of occasional markets.

- In 1444, an urbanization project was completed, creating a wide space for strolling, leisure, and markets.
- During the Middle Ages, a network of roads emerged around Barcelona, connecting the city to suburbs, villages, farmhouses, mills, quarries, churches, fountains, etc.
- Barcelona became part of the Hispanic Monarchy in the Early Modern Age, which brought periods of prosperity and economic crisis due to plagues and conflicts.
- The city's population approached 100,000 by the end of the Early Modern Age, but urban reforms were limited due to the loss of Barcelona's capital status.
- In the 16th century, a sea wall was built with bastions, and the Plaça de la Seu and Plaça de San Iu were opened near the cathedral.
- An artificial port was constructed in the 15th and 16th centuries to accommodate Barcelona's significant mercantile activity.
- The Passeig del Mar, now Passeig de Colom, was created with the port's construction, and water supply and sewage systems were improved.
- In the 17th century, the city wall was expanded with five new gates, streets were paved, sewers were installed, and drinking water fountains were built.
- The Principality of Catalonia and Barcelona lost much of their autonomy with the victory of Philip V in the War of Succession (1716), as the Generalitat, Corts, and Consell de Cent were eliminated.

- In the 18th century, Barcelona saw a decrease in autonomy after the War of Succession and the victory of Philip V.
- The Nueva Planta Decree (1716) eliminated the Generalitat, the Corts, and the Consell de Cent, replacing them with a military government.
- Municipal jurisdiction was reduced to the city, and the economy became progressively industrialized, leading to the Industrial Revolution.
- The Bourbons initiated military engineering works, such as the castle of Montjuïc and the fortress of the Citadel.
- The Citadel (1715-1751) resulted in 1200 houses in the Ribera neighborhood being demolished, leaving 4500 people homeless without compensation, and the Rec Comtal being diverted.
- Two new military roads were constructed: the Mataró road (current Pere IV street) and the Creu Coberta road, connecting with the Madrid road (current Hostafrancs and Sants streets).
- In 1753, the construction of the neighborhood of La Barceloneta began, designed by the engineer Pedro Martín Cermeño with a grid of orthogonal streets and elongated house blocks, showcasing academic baroque urbanism.
- The Clock Tower, the first lighthouse of the city, was established in 1772, followed by the Llobregat in 1845 and Montjuïc in 1925.
- The Edicto de obreria (1771) was approved, controlling private works in the city, regulating the alignment of houses, paving of streets, sewage system, numbering of houses, and requiring building permits with reports and fees.
- A height limit for all buildings was established in 1797.
- The typology of private buildings changed from "artisan houses" to "multi-family houses" with collective staircases, separating work from residence.
- The redevelopment of La Rambla (1776-1778) transformed an ancient torrent into a landscaped promenade, and the paseos of Sant Joan and Gràcia were planned.

- During the 18th century, Born and Boqueria markets were established, and aspects such as weights and measures for food products and coal marketing were regulated in 1752.
- The 19th century brought significant economic revitalization, primarily linked to the textile industry, leading to a Catalan cultural renaissance.
- Barcelona's city walls were demolished between 1854 and 1859, allowing urban expansion under the Eixample project by Ildefons Cerdà.
- The Citadel was demolished after the 1868 revolution, and the land was transformed into a public park.
- Barcelona's population grew to 400,000 inhabitants by the end of the 19th century, mainly due to immigration from other parts of Spain.
- The industrial era began in Barcelona with the founding of the Bonaplata Factory in 1832, followed by the establishment of La España Industrial in 1849.
- Textile and metallurgical industries grew steadily, with factories such as La Barcelonesa (1841) and La Maquinista Terrestre y Marítima (1855) playing crucial roles.
- Industrialization led to important changes in urban planning, with a focus on labor concentration, urban-industrial development, and improved transportation networks.

- In 1856, the first Ordenanzas Municipales were approved, requiring building permit layout plans for the first time.

- In 1854, the railway stations of Francia, Sants, and Norte were constructed, making Barcelona the center of a railway network shaped like a "Catalan eight."
- By the 1880s, Barcelona had links with France, Madrid, Zaragoza, Valencia, and other Catalan provincial capitals.
- Two companies operated the railways: Ferrocarril del Norte and MZA, which were integrated into RENFE in 1941.
- Barcelona's first fire and police services were established in the mid-19th century.
  - The Guardia Urbana de Barcelona was created in 1843, responsible for public safety and later traffic control.

- In 1908, animal-drawn vehicles were replaced by motor vehicles, and firefighters were professionalized in 1913.
- The Diputation of Barcelona developed new road layouts in the Barcelona plain, including Sarrià road (now Sarrià Avenue), the road from Sants to Les Corts, and the road from Sagrera to Horta (now Garcilaso Street).
- The port was expanded in the mid-19th century with a new wharf and dredging by engineer José Rafo.
- The telegraph service started in 1855, with a radial network centered in Madrid and later extended to Valencia, Seville, and A Coruña.

- In the 18th and 19th centuries, Barcelona's population grew significantly, leading to high population density and health concerns.
- Despite calls for the city's expansion, the government opposed demolishing the city walls until a popular outcry led by Pedro Felipe Monlau resulted in permission to demolish them in 1854.
- In 1859, the City Council held a competition for urban expansion projects, which was won by Antoni Rovira i Trias, but the Ministry of Development imposed Ildefons Cerdà's project instead.
- Cerdà's plan, implemented in 1859, featured an orthogonal layout with 20-meter-wide streets and chamfered buildings for better circulation.
- The plan called for the construction of several main avenues, large squares, and new ring roads, as well as green spaces and service areas.
- Cerdà's design included building height and depth restrictions, and a division of the Eixample into sectors, districts, and neighborhoods, each with specific facilities.
- Industrial and administrative facilities, a slaughterhouse, a cemetery, and three hospitals were also part of the plan, located in the suburbs.

- The walls were demolished in 1854, allowing for the city's territorial expansion.

- The Cerdà Plan, proposed by Ildefons Cerdà, was a design for the expansion of Barcelona, with buildings of 16 meters in height and 10-20 meters in depth, arranged in sectors of 20 x 20 blocks, divided into districts and neighborhoods.
 
- Each neighborhood was to have a church, civic center, school, day care center, nursing home, and other welfare centers, while each district was to have a market and each sector a park. There were also provisions for industrial and administrative facilities, and suburban areas had a slaughterhouse, cemetery, and three hospitals.

- However, many of these provisions were not realized due to opposition from the City Council and real estate speculation.

- Cerdà's project was based on three main points: hygienism, circulation, and multipurpose design. Hygienism involved improving living conditions and constructive elements; circulation involved making roads compatible for pedestrians and vehicles; and multipurpose design involved an urban layout that could be applied to both new and existing spaces.

- The Cerdà Plan was often superimposed on existing suburban layouts and had to take into account existing towns and their development projects, as well as highways, railroads, canals, and other land features.

- The naming of new streets in the Cerdà Plan was entrusted to writer Víctor Balaguer, who named them after territories linked to the Crown of Aragon, institutions, historical characters, battles, and events.

- A project for "interior renovations" was necessary to modernize the old core of the expanding city, with the first project by Miquel Garriga i Roca in 1862 proposing the realignment of streets. However, this project was not executed due to its difficulty and the absence of expropriation mechanisms.

- A more elaborate project was carried out by Àngel Baixeras in 1878, who presented an expropriation bill to the Senate in 1879. Baixeras' project envisaged a thorough remodeling of the old city, with the opening of three major thoroughfares to make the old city center more walkable.

- Miquel Garriga i Roca's joint plan of alignments (1862) was the first exhaustive plan of Barcelona, but its execution was paralyzed due to difficulties and absence of expropriation mechanisms.
- Àngel Baixeras' project (1878) envisioned a thorough remodeling of the old city, including the opening of three major thoroughfares. The project was approved in 1895 and partially realized in 1908 with the construction of Vía Laietana.
- The first omnibus line opened in 1860, followed by the introduction of the tramway in 1872, which was electrified in 1899.
- Antoni Rovira i Trias and Pere Falqués, as heads of Buildings and Ornamentation of the City Council, promoted the growth of street furniture, combining aesthetics and functionality.
- The installation of electric lighting began in the 1880s, gradually replacing gas lighting. The generalization of electric light was completed in 1929.
- The first telephone communication in the peninsula took place in Barcelona in 1877. The number of telephones in the city grew from 2479 in 1897 to 850,000 in 2000.
- Numerous supply markets were built in the last third of the century, many of them made of iron.

- In 1897, there were 2479 telephones in Barcelona, which grew to 850,000 by 2000.
- The Compañía Telefónica Nacional de España was created in 1925 by the dictatorship of Primo de Rivera.
- Numerous supply markets were built in the late 19th century, many made of iron, including the markets of Born, Sant Antoni, Hostafrancs, La Barceloneta, Concepción, Llibertat, Clot, Unió, Gràcia, and Sants.
- The 1888 Universal Exposition had a significant impact on the city, leading to improvements in infrastructure and modernization.
- The Citadel Park was remodeled by Josep Fontserè between 1872 and 1888, featuring gardens, a central square, a ring road, a monumental fountain, two lakes, and various auxiliary buildings.
- The Salón de San Juan and the Arc de Triomf were also remodeled for the Exposition.
- Many of the buildings and pavilions constructed for the Exposition were later demolished, but the Castle of the Three Dragons, the Martorell Museum, the Orangery, and the Umbraculum still remain.
- The Barcelona Zoo now occupies part of the park grounds.
- Numerous works and improvements were carried out throughout the city for the Exposition, including the completion of the urbanization of the city's seafront, the beginning of the urbanization of Plaça de Catalunya, the covering of Riera d'en Malla, the beginning of Avenue of Paral·lel, and the extension of Passeig de Sant Joan.
- Pere Garcia Fària's project to regulate the city's sewage system was implemented in 1891, with a unitary system for rainwater and wastewater and a visitable sewerage network maintained by a municipal brigade.

- Golondrinas, pleasure boats in Barcelona, have been in operation since the end of the 19th century.
- Pere Garcia Fària's project in 1891 regulated the city's sewage system, emphasizing hygienism and establishing a visitable sewerage network, which is still in use today.
- The increase in population and industrial needs led to a larger water collection and distribution network, with a new pipeline built from Dosrius in 1895.
- New hospitals were created to serve the growing population, such as Hospital Clínico y Provincial (1895-1906), Hospital de la Santa Creu i Sant Pau (1902-1930), and Hospital Universitari Vall d'Hebron (1955).
- The Eixample was progressively urbanized in several phases, from filling the area to constructing buildings, with the Comisiones Especiales de Ensanche appearing in 1892.
- Political and social changes in the 20th century included the end of the monarchy, the arrival of the Second Republic, the Civil War, Franco's dictatorship, and the reestablishment of the monarchy and democracy.
- Barcelona's population significantly increased from 530,000 inhabitants in 1900 to 1,500,000 by the end of the century.
- The loss of colonies in America and Asia, and the rise of the Regionalist League, led by politicians like Francesc Cambó, Enric Prat de la Riba, and architect Josep Puig i Cadafalch, aimed to place Barcelona on the international front line.

- The "Imperial Barcelona" or "Nova París del Migdia" was proposed by Prat de la Riba and Puig i Cadafalch, focusing on improving infrastructure, transport, equipment, creating a free port, addressing industrial society needs, increasing population, and education, culture, and green spaces.
- Barcelona annexed several neighboring towns between 1897 and 1943, expanding from 15.5 km² to 77.8 km² and increasing its population from 383,908 to 559,589.
- In 1903, an International Competition was held for connecting the city and the newly annexed municipalities, won by French town planner Léon Jaussely.
- Jaussely's Plan, based on a structural scheme with differentiated urban fabric treatment, included main axes (radial roads and ring roads), zoning of activities, and green space systematization.
- The Plan envisioned large road infrastructures, parks, gardens, rail links, public buildings, facilities, and service areas, but was only partially realized.
- In 1908, Via Laietana was opened, connecting the Eixample with the sea, as per the Plan Baixeras of 1878. Most buildings along Via Laietana are of noucentista appearance with some Chicago School influence.
- Criticism of Via Laietana's construction led to the halting of other planned roads, but some punctual interventions were made according to projects by Antoni Darder (1918), Joaquim Vilaseca (1932), and Soteras-Bordoy (1956).

- The new road in Barcelona was built with a uniform appearance, mostly of noucentista style with some influence from the Chicago School.
- The construction of two other roads were planned but not carried out due to criticism and paralysis of the works.
- In the early 1900s, the slopes of Tibidabo were urbanized with a wide avenue linking the avenue of San Gervasio with the mountain, occupied by single-family houses in the style of English garden cities.
- A tramway was installed on the avenue and a funicular to ascend to the top of the mountain (1901) and the Tibidabo Amusement Park was located there.
- The Vallvidrera funicular was also opened in 1906.
- An urbanization project of the Can Muntaner estate (1900-1914) was designed as a garden city of single-family houses, promoted by the industrialist Eusebi Güell and designed by Antoni Gaudí.
- The port was enlarged between 1905 and 1912 with a project by Julio Valdés, giving the port its current physiognomy.
- The general electrification of the city took place in the early 1900s, with the foundation of Barcelona Traction Light and Power in 1911.
- Public urinals called vespasianas were installed, made of metal with a circular body, but were removed in the 1910s.
- The tramway network was extended in the early 1900s, with companies such as Les Tramways de Barcelone Société Anonyme.
- The first buses appeared in 1906, but the service was suppressed in 1908 due to protests from the tramway companies.
